info.title: PostHog Python SDK
info.description: Integrate PostHog into any python application.

classes.title: PostHog
classes.description: This is the SDK reference for the PostHog Python SDK. You can learn more about example usage in the [Python SDK documentation](/docs/libraries/python). You can also follow [Flask](/docs/libraries/flask) and [Django](/docs/libraries/django) guides to integrate PostHog into your project.

functions.title: Client
functions.description: Initialize a new PostHog client instance.

params.name: host
params.description: The host to use for the client.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
from posthog import Posthog

posthog = Posthog('<ph_project_api_key>', host='<ph_app_host>')

functions.title: alias
functions.description: Create an alias between two distinct IDs.

params.name: distinct_id
params.description: The new distinct ID to alias to.

params.name: uuid
params.description: A unique identifier for the event.

params.name: disable_geoip
params.description: Whether to disable GeoIP for this event.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code: posthog.alias(previous_id='distinct_id', distinct_id='alias_id')

functions.title: capture
functions.description: Captures an event manually. [Learn about capture best practices](https://posthog.com/docs/product-analytics/capture-events)

examples.name: Anonymous event
examples.code:
# Anonymous event
posthog.capture('some-anon-event')

examples.name: Context usage
examples.code:
# Context usage
from posthog import identify_context, new_context
with new_context():
    identify_context('distinct_id_of_the_user')
    posthog.capture('user_signed_up')
    posthog.capture('user_logged_in')
    posthog.capture('some-custom-action', distinct_id='distinct_id_of_the_user')

examples.name: Set event properties
Page view event
examples.code:
# Page view event
posthog.capture('$pageview', distinct_id="distinct_id_of_the_user", properties={'$current_url': 'https://example.com'})

functions.title: capture_exception
functions.description: Capture an exception for error tracking.

examples.name: Example 1

functions.title: feature_enabled
functions.description: Check if a feature flag is enabled for a user.

params.name: distinct_id
params.description: The distinct ID of the user.

params.name: send_feature_flag_events
params.description: Whether to send feature flag events.

params.name: disable_geoip
params.description: Whether to disable GeoIP for this request.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
is_my_flag_enabled = posthog.feature_enabled('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')
if is_my_flag_enabled:
    # Do something differently for this user
    # Optional: fetch the payload
    matched_flag_payload = posthog.get_feature_flag_payload('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')

functions.title: flush
functions.description: Force a flush from the internal queue to the server. Do not use directly, call `shutdown()` instead.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
posthog.capture('event_name')
posthog.flush()  # Ensures the event is sent immediately

functions.title: get_all_flags
functions.description: Get all feature flags for a user.

params.name: distinct_id
params.description: The distinct ID of the user.

params.name: disable_geoip
params.description: Whether to disable GeoIP for this request.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code: posthog.get_all_flags('distinct_id_of_your_user')

functions.title: get_all_flags_and_payloads
functions.description: Get all feature flags and their payloads for a user.

params.name: distinct_id
params.description: The distinct ID of the user.

params.name: disable_geoip
params.description: Whether to disable GeoIP for this request.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code: posthog.get_all_flags_and_payloads('distinct_id_of_your_user')

functions.title: get_feature_flag
functions.description: Get multivariate feature flag value for a user.

params.name: distinct_id
params.description: The distinct ID of the user.

params.name: send_feature_flag_events
params.description: Whether to send feature flag events.

params.name: disable_geoip
params.description: Whether to disable GeoIP for this request.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
enabled_variant = posthog.get_feature_flag('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')
if enabled_variant == 'variant-key': # replace 'variant-key' with the key of your variant
    # Do something differently for this user
    # Optional: fetch the payload
    matched_flag_payload = posthog.get_feature_flag_payload('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')

functions.title: get_feature_flag_payload
functions.description: Get the payload for a feature flag.

params.name: distinct_id
params.description: The distinct ID of the user.

params.name: match_value
params.description: The specific flag value to get payload for.

params.name: send_feature_flag_events
params.description: Whether to send feature flag events.

params.name: disable_geoip
params.description: Whether to disable GeoIP for this request.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
is_my_flag_enabled = posthog.feature_enabled('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')

if is_my_flag_enabled:
    # Do something differently for this user
    # Optional: fetch the payload
    matched_flag_payload = posthog.get_feature_flag_payload('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')

functions.title: get_feature_flag_result
functions.description: Get a FeatureFlagResult object which contains the flag result and payload for a key by evaluating locally or remotely depending on whether local evaluation is enabled and the flag can be locally evaluated. This also captures the `$feature_flag_called` event unless `send_feature_flag_events` is `False`.

params.name: distinct_id
params.description: The distinct ID of the user.

params.name: send_feature_flag_events
params.description: Whether to send feature flag events.

params.name: disable_geoip
params.description: Whether to disable GeoIP for this request.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
flag_result = posthog.get_feature_flag_result('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')
if flag_result and flag_result.get_value() == 'variant-key':
    # Do something differently for this user
    # Optional: fetch the payload
    matched_flag_payload = flag_result.payload

functions.title: get_feature_flags_and_payloads
functions.description: Get feature flags and payloads for a user by calling decide.

params.name: distinct_id
params.description: The distinct ID of the user.

params.name: disable_geoip

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code: result = posthog.get_feature_flags_and_payloads('<distinct_id>')

examples.name: Example 1

params.name: disable_geoip

params.name: disable_geoip

examples.name: Example 1

params.description: The unique identifier for the group.

params.name: properties

params.name: uuid
params.description: A unique identifier for the event.

params.name: disable_geoip

functions.description: End the consumer thread once the queue is empty. Do not use directly, call `shutdown()` instead.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code: posthog.join()

functions.title: new_context
functions.description: Create a new context for managing shared state. Learn more about [contexts](/docs/libraries/python#contexts).

params.name: fresh
params.description: Whether to create a fresh context that doesn't inherit from parent.

params.name: capture_exceptions
params.description: Whether to automatically capture exceptions in this context.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
with posthog.new_context():
    identify_context('<distinct_id>')
    posthog.capture('event_name')

functions.title: set
functions.description: Set properties on a person profile.

examples.name: Set with distinct id
Set using context
examples.code:
# Set using context
from posthog import new_context, identify_context
with new_context():
    identify_context('user-distinct-id')
    posthog.capture('event_name')

functions.title: set_once
functions.description: Set properties on a person profile only if they haven't been set before.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code: posthog.set_once(distinct_id='user123', properties={'initial_signup_date': '2024-01-01'})

functions.title: shutdown
functions.description: Flush all messages and cleanly shutdown the client. Call this before the process ends in serverless environments to avoid data loss.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code: posthog.shutdown()

classes.title: PostHog Module Functions
classes.description: Global functions available in the PostHog module

functions.title: alias
functions.description: Associate user behaviour before and after they e.g. register, login, or perform some other identifying action.
functions.details: To marry up whatever a user does before they sign up or log in with what they do after you need to make an alias call. This will allow you to answer questions like "Which marketing channels leads to users churning after a month?" or "What do users do on our website before signing up?". Particularly useful for associating user behaviour before and after they e.g. register, login, or perform some other identifying action.

params.name: previous_id
params.description: The unique ID of the user before

examples.name: Alias user
examples.code:
# Alias user
from posthog import alias
alias(previous_id='distinct_id', distinct_id='alias_id')

functions.title: capture
functions.description: Capture anything a user does within your system.
functions.details: Capture allows you to capture anything a user does within your system, which you can later use in PostHog to find patterns in usage, work out which features to improve or where people are giving up. A capture call requires an event name to specify the event. We recommend using [verb] [noun], like `movie played` or `movie updated` to easily identify what your events mean later on. Capture takes a number of optional arguments, which are defined by the `OptionalCaptureArgs` type.

params.name: event
params.description: The event name to specify the event     **kwargs: Optional arguments including:

examples.name: Context and capture usage
examples.code:
# Context and capture usage
from posthog import new_context, identify_context, tag_context, capture
# Enter a new context (e.g. a request/response cycle, an instance of a background job, etc)
with new_context():
    # Associate this context with some user, by distinct_id
    identify_context('some user')

    # Capture an event, associated with the context-level distinct ID ('some user')
    capture('movie started')

    # Capture an event associated with some other user (overriding the context-level distinct ID)
    capture('movie joined', distinct_id='some-other-user')

    # Capture an event with some properties
    capture('movie played', properties={'movie_id': '123', 'category': 'romcom'})

    # Capture an event with some properties
    capture('purchase', properties={'product_id': '123', 'category': 'romcom'})
    # Capture an event with some associated group
    capture('purchase', groups={'company': 'id:5'})

    # Adding a tag to the current context will cause it to appear on all subsequent events
    tag_context('some-tag', 'some-value')

    capture('another-event') # Will be captured with `'some-tag': 'some-value'` in the properties dict

examples.name: Set event properties

functions.title: capture_exception
functions.description: Capture exceptions that happen in your code.
functions.details: Capture exception is idempotent - if it is called twice with the same exception instance, only a occurrence will be tracked in posthog. This is because, generally, contexts will cause exceptions to be captured automatically. However, to ensure you track an exception, if you catch and do not re-raise it, capturing it manually is recommended, unless you are certain it will have crossed a context boundary (e.g. by existing a `with posthog.new_context():` block already). If the passed exception was raised and caught, the captured stack trace will consist of every frame between where the exception was raised and the point at which it is captured (the "traceback"). If the passed exception was never raised, e.g. if you call `posthog.capture_exception(ValueError("Some Error"))`, the stack trace captured will be the full stack trace at the moment the exception was captured. Note that heavy use of contexts will lead to truncated stack traces, as the exception will be captured by the context entered most recently, which may not be the point you catch the exception for the final time in your code. It's recommended to use contexts sparingly, for this reason. `capture_exception` takes the same set of optional arguments as `capture`.

params.name: exception
params.description: The exception to capture. If not provided, the current exception is captured via `sys.exc_info()`

examples.name: Capture exception

functions.title: feature_enabled
functions.description: Use feature flags to enable or disable features for users.
functions.details: You can call `posthog.load_feature_flags()` before to make sure you're not doing unexpected requests.

params.name: send_feature_flag_events
params.description: Whether to send feature flag events

examples.name: Boolean feature flag
examples.code:
# Boolean feature flag
from posthog import feature_enabled, get_feature_flag_payload
is_my_flag_enabled = feature_enabled('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')
if is_my_flag_enabled:
    matched_flag_payload = get_feature_flag_payload('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')

functions.title: feature_flag_definitions
functions.description: Returns loaded feature flags.
functions.details: Returns loaded feature flags, if any. Helpful for debugging what flag information you have loaded.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
from posthog import feature_flag_definitions
definitions = feature_flag_definitions()

functions.title: flush
functions.description: Tell the client to flush all queued events.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
from posthog import flush
flush()

functions.title: get_all_flags
functions.description: Get all flags for a given user.
functions.details: Flags are key-value pairs where the key is the flag key and the value is the flag variant, or True, or False.

examples.name: All flags for user
examples.code:
# All flags for user
from posthog import get_all_flags
get_all_flags('distinct_id_of_your_user')

functions.title: get_feature_flag
functions.description: Get feature flag variant for users. Used with experiments.
functions.details: `groups` are a mapping from group type to group key. So, if you have a group type of "organization" and a group key of "5", you would pass groups={"organization": "5"}. `group_properties` take the format: { group_type_name: { group_properties } }. So, for example, if you have the group type "organization" and the group key "5", with the properties name, and employee count, you'll send these as: group_properties={"organization": {"name": "PostHog", "employees": 11}}.

params.name: groups
params.description: Groups mapping from group type to group key

params.name: group_properties
params.description: Group properties in format { group_type_name: { group_properties } }

params.name: send_feature_flag_events
params.description: Whether to send feature flag events

examples.name: Multivariate feature flag
examples.code:
# Multivariate feature flag
from posthog import get_feature_flag, get_feature_flag_payload
enabled_variant = get_feature_flag('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')
if enabled_variant == 'variant-key':
    matched_flag_payload = get_feature_flag_payload('flag-key', 'distinct_id_of_your_user')

functions.title: get_remote_config_payload
functions.description: Get the payload for a remote config feature flag.

params.name: key
params.description: The key of the feature flag

functions.title: group_identify
functions.description: Set properties on a group.

params.name: properties
params.description: Properties to set on the group

examples.name: Group identify

functions.title: identify_context
functions.description: Identify the current context with a distinct ID.

params.name: distinct_id
params.description: The distinct ID to associate with the current context and its children

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
from posthog import identify_context
identify_context("user_123")

functions.title: join
functions.description: Block program until the client clears the queue. Used during program shutdown. You should use `shutdown()` directly in most cases.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
from posthog import join
join()

functions.title: load_feature_flags
functions.description: Load feature flag definitions from PostHog.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
from posthog import load_feature_flags
load_feature_flags()

functions.title: new_context
functions.description: Create a new context scope that will be active for the duration of the with block.

params.name: fresh
params.description: Whether to start with a fresh context (default: False)

params.name: capture_exceptions
params.description: Whether to capture exceptions raised within the context (default: True)

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
from posthog import new_context, tag, capture
with new_context():
    tag("request_id", "123")
    capture("event_name", properties={"property": "value"})

functions.title: scoped
functions.description: Decorator that creates a new context for the function.

params.name: fresh
params.description: Whether to start with a fresh context (default: False)

params.name: capture_exceptions
params.description: Whether to capture and track exceptions with posthog error tracking (default: True)

examples.name: Example 1

functions.title: set
functions.description: Set properties on a user record.
functions.details: This will overwrite previous people property values. Generally operates similar to `capture`, with distinct_id being an optional argument, defaulting to the current context's distinct ID. If there is no context-level distinct ID, and no override distinct_id is passed, this function will do nothing. Context tags are folded into $set properties, so tagging the current context and then calling `set` will cause those tags to be set on the user (unlike capture, which causes them to just be set on the event).

examples.name: Set person properties

functions.title: set_context_session
functions.description: Set the session ID for the current context.

params.name: session_id
params.description: The session ID to associate with the current context and its children

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
from posthog import set_context_session
set_context_session("session_123")

functions.title: set_once
functions.description: Set properties on a user record, only if they do not yet exist.
functions.details: This will not overwrite previous people property values, unlike `set`. Otherwise, operates in an identical manner to `set`.

examples.name: Set property once

functions.title: shutdown
functions.description: Flush all messages and cleanly shutdown the client.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
from posthog import shutdown
shutdown()

functions.title: tag
functions.description: Add a tag to the current context.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
from posthog import tag
tag("user_id", "123")
